Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Energy Synchronized Computing in Sustainable Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: With the increasing demand of ubiquitous sensing and cyber-physical interaction, wireless sensor networks have emerged as one of the key technologies for many long-term applications such as such as habitat monitoring, microclimate study, structural integrity analysis, precise agriculture, traffic engineering and assisted living. Compared with competing high-end technologies, sensor networks are acclaimed as low-cost, low-profile, and easy to deploy. These attractive advantages, however, imply that resources available to individual nodes are severely limited. Among them, energy constraint is by far the most critical hurdle hindering the practical deployment of this emerging technology. A central challenge addressed by this project is to sustain the operation of wireless sensor networks for years in energy-dynamic environments. The driven idea of this project is energy-synchronized computing ?a holistic approach to synchronize sensor network activities with dynamic energy supply from the environments. The expected deliveries of this project are (i) the design and implementation of sustainable sensor nodes, (ii) the architecture principles, theoretical insights, design methodologies, and protocols for sustainable networking technology, (iii) the running prototype systems for long-term sustainable applications, and (iv) the educational test-beds, outreach activities for K-12 students and minority groups, and curriculum designs for undergraduate and graduate courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project builds sustainable sensor networks for long-term applications in energy-dynamic environments. The driven idea is energy-synchronized computing— a holistic and systematic approach to synchronize sensor network activities with dynamic energy supply from the environments. This technology enables many long-term applications such as habitat monitoring, infrastructure protection, scientific exploration, assisted living, and military surveillance.  

Technologies Innovation: During the course of the project, we offered empirical evidence that the use of ultra-capacitors motivates many opportunities and research challenges substantially different from the legacy battery-based solutions. We have designed TwinStar, which utilizes ultra-capacitors as the primary energy storage controlled by a novel leakage-aware technique to overcome the intrinsic limitations of batteries. In this work, we design and implement leakage-aware feedback control techniques for TwinStar devices and related communication protocols to match effectively the network-wide activity with the dynamic energy supply from environments.

We worked on the power storage and management design in micro grids. The ability to move energy around makes it feasible to build distributed energy storage systems that can robustly extend the lifetime of networked sensor systems. We developed eShare which supports the concept of energy sharing among multiple embedded sensor devices by providing designs for energy routers (i.e., energy storage and routing devices) and related energy access and network protocols. For the first time, we demonstrate that we can apply data networking technology to distribute energy among devices. We also designed smart battery management systems to optimize energy efficiency using adaptive power reconfiguration, which is critical for electric vehicles and energy backup in power grids.

As battery-powered mobile devices become more popular and energy hungry, wireless power transfer technology receives intensive interests, as it allows the power to be transferred from a charger to ambient devices wirelessly. The existing studies mainly focus on the power transfer efficiency but overlook the health impairments caused by RF exposure.  We are the first group proposing and studying the safe charging problem, attempting to strike the best tradeoff between the charging efficiency and EMR safety. Given a set of wireless power chargers and rechargeable devices, we designed charger-scheduling schemes so that the devices can obtain more power, while no location exceeds the EMR safety threshold.

Long-term operation of wireless sensor devices requires an energy-efficient communication design. For years, many researchers have been ignoring the fact that idle listening accounts for most of the energy consumption in wireless communication. To reduce energy, we have to operate wireless sensor devices in a low duty cycle mode. This project has conducted pioneered research in various aspects of low-duty-cycle networking, a technology that allows small electronic devices to sustain for months and even years for long-term operation.

According to the Google Scholar, our research have collectively gathered over 17,000 citations (h-index 52), a number that grows 1,600 annually in recent years. The citation directly related to this project has exceeded 3000 in just six years.

Computer Science Education and Mentoring: This project leads to two new courses, a graduate-level course on wireless sensor networks (CS8221) and an undergraduate-level course on wireless ad hoc networks (CS5231). In both course, the concept of sustainable energy aware networks has been introduced.
